Hi team! Great to see you.

It looks like you're trying to start a Sprint Execution meeting—sorry, but we need the exact magic words for the system to kick it off. Please type: `start sprint execution meeting` or `start sprint meeting`. Once you do, we'll get the team rolling on building out the sprint!
Hi team! I'm geared up for sprint execution—let me know what tasks Mike has queued up for implementation.
who can tell me how to use this app
No comment (reason: no_trigger)
No comment (reason: no_trigger)

Hi team! As the Project Manager and facilitator, I can walk you through it. Agile in a Box is a chat-based app where our AI team (me, Mike the Architect, Jordan the Tester, and Alex the Developer) collaborates with you on projects using Agile sprints—start by describing your vision or requesting a meeting like "start vision meeting" to kick things off!
I'm the architect here—best to ask Sarah for general app usage guidance, as she's our facilitator.
got ya sarah can you give me a 1 paragraph understanding of how the app works
No comment (reason: not_addressed)
No comment (reason: not_addressed)
No comment (reason: not_addressed)

Sarah: Absolutely! Agile in a Box is a collaborative chat app from ai-diy that simulates an Agile software development team to help you build projects efficiently—our AI personas (me as the Project Manager guiding vision and meetings, Mike as Architect designing structure, Alex as Developer implementing code, and Jordan as Tester ensuring quality) work together in a single conversation with you. We operate in structured sprints triggered by meeting requests like "start vision meeting" to define scope, refine requirements, plan tasks, build and test deliverables, then review and iterate; the Scribe automatically records decisions and progress, so you focus on guiding the direction while we handle the heavy lifting in an automated, client-friendly workflow.
what meetings do we need to progress though to create an app
No comment (reason: no_trigger)

Sarah: To create an app using Agile in a Box, we progress through a structured sequence of meetings to ensure clarity and alignment: start with a Vision Meeting to define the project's high-level goals and name it; follow with a Requirements Meeting to build and prioritize the backlog of features; then enter Sprint Planning to break it into actionable tasks for the first sprint; after our team implements and tests (via inner loops), we hold a Sprint Review to demo the deliverable and gather your feedback; finally, a Sprint Retrospective to reflect and improve before the next sprint—repeat as needed until the app is complete! If you're ready, just say "start vision meeting" to begin.
No comment (reason: no_trigger)

Sarah: To create an app in Agile in a Box, we progress through a structured sequence of meetings that align with Agile sprints: start with the "vision meeting" to define the high-level idea and goals; then "requirements meeting" to detail features and user stories; followed by "sprint planning" to break down tasks and assign work; "daily standup" for quick progress checks (optional but recommended); "sprint review" to demo and gather feedback on deliverables; and "retrospective" to reflect and improve. This cycle repeats for iterations until the app is complete—initiate any by saying e.g., "start vision meeting" to begin!
how do i start and stop meetings
No comment (reason: no_trigger)
No comment (reason: no_trigger)

Sarah: To start a meeting, simply request it in the chat like "start vision meeting" or "start sprint planning"—I'll confirm the project name if needed and announce it to kick things off. Meetings naturally conclude when objectives are met (like sign-offs or decisions), but you can stop one anytime by saying "end [meeting type] meeting" to wrap up and return to general discussion.

No comment (reason: not_addressed)
No comment (reason: not_addressed)

Sarah: Great question! This app follows an Agile workflow to build your project iteratively: we start with a Vision Meeting to define the big picture and project name, then move into Requirements/Backlog Meetings to refine features and priorities, followed by Sprint Planning to break it down into actionable sprints, Sprint Reviews to demo and get your feedback, and Retrospectives to improve the process. To kick things off, just tell me you'd like to start a specific meeting, like "start vision meeting," and I'll guide us from there.
Sarah how do i start and end meetings
No comment (reason: not_addressed)
No comment (reason: not_addressed)
No comment (reason: not_addressed)

To start a meeting, just tell me (or the team) the type you'd like, such as "start vision meeting" or "sprint planning for ProjectX"—I'll confirm the project name if needed and announce it to kick things off. To end a meeting, say "end [meeting type]" or "wrap up," and we'll conclude with any key takeaways or next steps before transitioning.
